Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 09:01AM scorpio wrote: It's all about the plastic surgeon. You can read real horror stories about reconstruction and others that are extremely pleased. I was lucky, I had a unilateral mastectomy with a reduction on the other side for symmetry, and I one of the ones who is extremely pleased. My p.s.showed me pictures of his work in cases exactly like mine. I was recommended to him by my breast surgeon who works with him all the time. He only does breast reconstruction. Not every plastic surgeon is an expert in breast reconstruction. If you get a good surgeon, you can get a good result. The most important factor, before the technique, is the surgeon. I know not everyone lives in a metropolitan area where they have access to choices, but it might be worth travelling farther to go to someone with a really good reputation. Hope this helps

Posts.Content: scorpio wrote: o.k. so back dec.05 when I was diagnosed the breast onc and the breast surgeon both staged me at stage 2 which they both reassured me they considered "early stage." Fast forward to last month when I went for my mamo and was discussing my reservations about hormone therapy, A I's in particular and my surgeon says,"well, with stage III..." and I'm ...wait, back up here, I'm stage 2 , not stage 3,(thinking she just made a mistake) and she says, oh no with your largest tumor more than 10 cm, lymph node involvement, her2+, you're definitely stage III, but IIIa(trying to make it better) and I'm like, nobody told me and she pulls up the path report and shows me the 10cm tumor and I say, well where does it say stage !!!?(of course, it didn't) Anyway one week later meet with the breast onc(not my regular onc, she was on personal leave) and I tell her I'm still gettin over the shock of knowing I'm stage 3(honestly I felt exactly the same as when I was first diagnosed) and she was extremely nonchalant and basically said that..oh stage 3 is just a guide for us(them docs) to recommend treatment. Then she said "basically you're either stage 4 or you're not." So I say , but my research on the internet shows that the overall survival rates and recurrence change from 2 to 3. Well, she just pooh-poohed that. I'm here on this forum, cuz I'm trying to decide what kind of treatment to continue with. I have serious issures with a.i's(not just the s.e.s, but the whole rationale) so I thought that going back to tamoxifen would be a good compromise., but since making that decision, I've been on the ever escalting tamoxifen testing ...trans-vag ultra sound leads to endometrial biopsy, leads to dnc, hysteroscopy, polyectomy...now I don't know. If I still thought I was stage 2, I'd stop all hormonals, but a stage 3 perspective is different. I don't know how to think anymore, I don't know what I'm looking for here, maybe just the comaraderie of stage 3rs,nobody knows what it's like...it's like a fuzzy area, you're not "early stage" and you're not stage 4, it's weird. Well, thanks for listening. Scorpio Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 05:53AM scorpio wrote: Hi Brenda I really agree with Laurie on the post-mastectomy camisole.My surgeon recommended it and it was a real blessing. They put on a surgical velcro bra on in surgery which I woke up with and wore until the drains came out.So it was the surgical bra and the camisole over that. I had my drains for about2 weeks. I wore a big shirt over the camisole. After that the sports bra with the zip-up front(recommended by my plastic surgeon, I had immediate reconstruction.) I really didn't feel much like going out before the drains came out anyway. I've since  had a final reconstruction, with a reduction on the other side for symmetry.(It sounds as if you are probably the same size as me) I 'm very satisfied with the final result...very youthful. Good Luck with your surgery. Hope this helps Scorpio
